Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Class-Specific Transformations of Antibiotics in UV-Based Water/Wastewater Treatment Processes

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1510420
Blaney

The proposed work focuses on ultraviolet-based transformation reactions for three classes of antibiotics: fluoroquinolones, tetracyclines, and sulfonamides. The blockbuster drugs (e.g., ciprofloxacin, tetracycline, sulfamethoxazole) in these classes have been extensively studied; however, the behavior of these compounds during ultraviolet -driven water/wastewater treatment processes does not necessarily extend to other compounds within the same class. Furthermore, a potential for antibiotic transformation into other antibiotics exists. The overall objective of this project is to provide a comprehensive understanding of ultraviolet-based reactions of 40 compounds from three critical antibiotic classes.

The project will include antibiotics of concern including 15 fluoroquinolones, 10 tetracyclines, and 15 sulfonamides. The hypothesis is that a significant potential for antibiotic-to-antibiotic transformation exists during ultraviolet -based processes. This avenue for antibiotic generation during water/wastewater treatment is critical to lowering the risks associated with antibiotic concentrations in finished water and wastewater effluent. This hypothesis will be tested by the following Specific Aims: 1. To develop an online solid-phase extraction liquid chromatography electrospray ionization tandem mass spectrometry analytical method for 40 antibiotics. 2. To measure reaction kinetics and antibiotic transformation with ultraviolet light at 253.7 nm and hydroxyl radicals in synthetic solutions, finished water, and wastewater effluent. 3. To identify antibiotic-to-antibiotic transformations within each class and construct reaction pathways to demonstrate potential for residual antimicrobial activity after ultraviolet treatment. 4. To characterize the residual antimicrobial activity of treated solutions (i.e., synthetic, drinking water, and wastewater) containing ultraviolet transformation products. The approach is a multi-pronged research strategy which will increase understanding of the fate of an increasingly important class of chemicals in water and wastewater. Awareness of antibiotic-to-antibiotic transformations within specific classes has been confined to natural systems, not engineered ultraviolet processes. The proposed study represents transformative research that challenges conventional wisdom surrounding transformation of antibiotics in ultraviolet processes. Another transformative quality of this project derives from the emphasis on a class-based approach to study of pharmaceutical and personal care products, rather than a large investigation of chemically-diverse molecules. The expected benefits of the proposed research include measurement of specific molar absorptivity, quantum yield, and fluence-based pseudo-first order rate constants; determination of second-order rate constants for antibiotic reaction with hydroxyl radicals; identification of phototransformation products/pathways for antibiotics; and characterization of the toxicity of transformation products. To better understand the impact of the national prescription drug take-back day program on preventing pharmaceuticals from entering the aquatic environment, the PI will be working with a DEA Special Agent to gather quantitative data on future collections. In particular, the PI proposes identifying and massing all prescription drugs deposited at the UMBC and Howard County Police Departments each year.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Antibiotics have been increasingly detected in water supplies, raising concerns about their potential impacts on the development and spread of antibiotic resistance. To offset these concerns, advanced treatment processes are needed to effectively remove antibiotics from water and wastewater. The incorporation of UV disinfection processes in drinking water and wastewater treatment plants enables direct photolysis of antibiotics and, in some instances, photochemical advanced oxidation of antibiotics. Both degradation mechanisms transform antibiotics into other molecules, and the transformation products often retain key elements of the chemical structure that result in antibiotic properties. The residual antimicrobial activity of treated water can be assessed using bacteria growth inhibition bioassays.

In all of the aforementioned areas, we identified knowledge gaps. For example, monitoring campaigns for antibiotics have mostly focused on locations where these contaminants are expected to be present (e.g., wastewater effluent) and other sites have been largely ignored. While several studies have reported the fate of specific antibiotics in particular water sources, few have calculated the fundamental, species-specific parameters needed to understand the photodegradation kinetics of antibiotics as a function of water quality (e.g., solution pH). Similarly, select studies have reported the formation of antimicrobially-active transformation products, but a targeted approach using a large suite of known, marketed antibiotics from the same class has not been reported for UV disinfection systems. Finally, the antimicrobial activity assay used by previous researchers was adopted from pharmacology literature without optimization for environmental applications. These knowledge gaps motivated our work on this project.

The overall goal of this project was to provide a comprehensive understanding of the reactions of 40 compounds from three critical antibiotic classes in UV-based processes. The antibiotics of concern included 15 fluoroquinolones, 10 tetracyclines, and 15 sulfonamides. We argued that studies focused on specific antibiotic classes would provide important insight, especially with respect to potential antibiotic-to-antibiotic transformations in UV treatment processes. The project entailed four specific objectives:

  1. Develop an online solid-phase extraction liquid chromatography electrospray ionization tandem mass spectrometry (SPE-LC-ESI-MS/MS) analytical method for 40 antibiotics.
  2. Measure reaction kinetics and antibiotic transformation with UV light at 253.7 nm and hydroxyl radicals in synthetic solutions, finished water, and wastewater effluent.
  3. Identify antibiotic-to-antibiotic transformations within each class and construct reaction pathways to demonstrate potential for residual antimicrobial activity after UV treatment.
  4. Characterize the residual antimicrobial activity of treated solutions (i.e., synthetic, drinking water, and wastewater) containing UV transformation products.

Each objective generated intellectual merit. In Objective 1, we developed comprehensive SPE-LC-MS/MS analytical methods for measurement of 40+ antibiotics from the fluoroquinolone, macrolide, sulfonamide, and tetracycline classes. These methods were applied to measure antibiotics in urban streams (Baltimore, MD) and Chesapeake Bay rivers downstream of urban and agricultural areas, where diverse antibiotics were detected at relatively high concentrations. In Objective 2, we reported the molar absorption coefficients, fluence-based pseudo-first-order rate constants, and quantum yields for protonated and deprotonated antibiotic species. These three parameters can be used to (i) predict antibiotic transformation in drinking water and wastewater treatment processes or (ii) design UV treatment systems for a targeted transformation efficiency. Fluoroquinolones were the most reactive class of antibiotics, suggesting the highest potential for removal during UV treatment. In Objective 3, we identified fluoroquinolone-to-fluoroquinolone transformations for typical UV treatment conditions; furthermore, select transformation products were equally or more potent than the original antibiotic. Similar reactions were observed for sulfonamides, but the transformation product yield was low. These results reinforced the need to take a more holistic approach to antibiotic treatment. In Objective 4, we made key improvements to antimicrobial activity assay protocols that increased sensitivity more than 100× for select antibiotics. The biggest improvements were attained for macrolide and sulfonamide antibiotics, enabling deployment of this important bioassay technique at concentrations that are more environmentally relevant.

The broader impacts of the project were focused on education, training, and professional development of students. Three PhD students, five BS students, one high school student, and one postdoctoral research associate were involved with the project. To increase diversity and improve representation in environmental engineering, we prioritized training of students from underrepresented groups. In particular, five women, three African Americans, one Hispanic American, and one student with a disability conducted experimental activities associated with the intellectual merit described above. All ten students gave or co-authored presentations at regional and national conferences, and all students will co-author at least one publication from this project. The PI also conducted outreach to various campus organizations, including the Center for Women in Technology, the Meyerhoff Scholars Program, and the Office of Undergraduate Education. The aims of the outreach activities were to inspire, encourage, and guide students to undergraduate research opportunities. Ultimately, the technical and educational outcomes of this project help to reduce antibiotic concentrations in drinking water, decrease antibiotic discharge into the environment, and slow the development of antimicrobial resistance.
